content.description: Look for an old bolt about 40 feet off the deck. Climb to the bolt, then climb on the outside of a thin flake that makes weird sounds as you climb...at the top of this...clip another old bolt and then make a few steeper moves to a belay.
content.protection: two old bolts...some small cams and stoppers for belay.
content.location: A slab climb located about 50 yards north of the pear and apple.

content.description: The crux on To Steep for Sheep is getting off the ground.  After getting established on the route its fun climbing on left facing hold to the top.
content.protection: 4 quick draws   Fixed anchors are located back about 15-20 ft.
content.location: Located just to the left of Science Friction.

content.description: The longest single word route name in the World!  Awesome bolted line that travels just left of nose of the the big face below the apple and the pear. Very continuous and kinda runout.
content.location: Just below the Pear and Apple.

content.description: Face climb on the slab 50 yards down and to the left of the pear and apple route. Climb up on good friction to a bolt; continue on the face on runout climbing to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: On a separate wall than "too steep for sheep", if you are looking at pear and apple from the trail, science friction is the slab face one over to the left from the obvious black slabs at the base of pear and apple.

content.description: Climb easy crack system to the left of pseudophycho, until the corner gets steep and runout. Place gear in corner as high as you can before launching up the smooth section.
content.protection: Nuts and cams from 0.25 to 4.0 inches. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Left of Pseudophycho... Rap or scramble off.

content.description: Take the trail from Sunset to the Pear and Apple boulder field. Hop a few boulders to the west side of the field. Follow the trail south a bit, take the side trail that heads under the boulder field. Follow the cave system to the east making your way to the top of the boulders and up to the walls below Pear and Apple. I'm sure there's an easier way to get to this climb, but this way is soooo much more fun. Follow the low angle water streak up to a bowled out area, continue up right and follow the natural moves. We did this route free-solo barefoot. The route is solid but leaves you feeling very exposed. Most of the climb is a scramble, but there are a few moves that felt like a 5.6 and one at the top that almost felt like a 5.7, but probably only felt that way because we had no shoes and it had just rained an hour before.
content.protection: I'm sure there's some spots for a piece or two, but you won't need it. This route is a great solo.
content.location: Low angle water streak North of Pear and Apple

content.description: Same start as pear and apple route. Climb up the corner, moving left and up onto the thin face moves protected by a pin. Formerly an aid line rated A2 until it went free.
A face climb on the right side of the prominent face nose. on old bolt about 40 feet up..then nothing.
content.protection: Toprope route - bolt is from a lead attempt a long long time ago.

content.description: Some great lines up some excellent rock.  Gets a lot of sun especially late so look here late fall and early spring as prime seasons.  Look for the prominet looking Pear and Apple boulder sitting atop the wall.
